--- Robert Sartin <sartin@...> wrote:
> A loop variant is usually an expression that results in a
> non-negative integer and the assertion is that the loop 
> invariant on pass n through a loop must be less than the loop 
> invariant on pass n-1.

Oops, those "invariant"s should have both said "variant". I do loop
invariants more often than I do loop variants and apparently my fingers
got ahead of my brain (which is not such a great challenge that they
ought to be proud of it).

The assertion about a loop invariant is, of course, that it is always
true at the ends of the loop.

Regards,

Rob
